author: Josiah Wolf

text: A game I've always wanted to play. I heard it's quite similar to Level 5's other series, Dark Cloud, is it indeed the case? I'm not the biggest Dark Cloud fan, but I still beat both games so I certainly had fun with them. Just never really liked randomized dungeons. This game's visuals are certainly pleasant and the music seems very nice. After this game, Nishiura went on to become Professor Layton's composer.

text: Possibly the most underrated RPG I've ever played. You gotta try it. I was skeptical and bought it on a whim. Got hooked from beginning to end. Still waiting on a sequel years later.
author: BaoZakeruga

text: Should give it a try. Its one of my all time favorite games. beautiful music, interesting characters and locations, Fun minigames and a good replay value. it always reminds me of a what-if thing if dark cloud developers did a star wars type game...a lot of the characters feel very star wars inspired. a boy from a desert planet dreaming of traveling into space. a tall lanky robot and a short and fat guy feel very¬†R2-D2 and C-3po ish. the boy not really knowing who his real parents were...a lot in the line of that kinda stuff. just a down right awesome sci-fi fantasy game in my opinion.¬†
author: VictorVonFox

text:
It's fairly similar.
The attacks feel a lot better because they're flat-out bigger, and you've got three people running around hitting things, so there's less of a panic around fighting big things. There's a pretty big hiccup with the whole party thing, though, and it's that Jaster is the only one who can use the context-specific guns you get. So you may be enjoying ripping things up as one character, and then - oh! An enemy with a shield! Now you HAVE to swap to Jaster to make it damageable. So there's THAT...
...and then there's what happens with at the end of the game with translations. I don't know who Level5 goes to for their translating, but they need to fire those people. Or set them ON fire.
Everything else is YMMV.
